id.desc: Component ID, not specified by default. If specified, it can be used to refer the component in option or API.

name.desc: Series name used for displaying in tooltip and filtering with legend, or updating data and configuration with setOption.

colorBy.desc:
Since v5.2.0

The policy to take color from option.color. Valid values:

  • 'series': assigns the colors in the palette by series, so that all data in the same series are in the same color;
  • 'data': assigns colors in the palette according to data items, with each data item using a different color.

zlevel.desc:
zlevel value of all graphical elements in .

zlevel is used to make layers with Canvas. Graphical elements with different zlevel values will be placed in different Canvases, which is a common optimization technique. We can put those frequently changed elements (like those with animations) to a separate zlevel. Notice that too many Canvases will increase memory cost, and should be used carefully on mobile phones to avoid crash.

Canvases with bigger zlevel will be placed on Canvases with smaller zlevel.

z.desc:
z value of all graphical elements in , which controls order of drawing graphical components. Components with smaller z values may be overwritten by those with larger z values.

z has a lower priority to zlevel, and will not create new Canvas.

center.desc:
Center position of , the first of which is the horizontal position, and the second is the vertical position.

Percentage is supported. When set in percentage, the item is relative to the container width, and the second item to the height.

Example: 

// Set to absolute pixel values
center: [400, 300]
// Set to relative percent
center: ['50%', '50%']

radius.desc: The radius of gauge chart. It can be a percentage value of the smaller of container half width and half height, also can be an absolute value.

legendHoverLink.desc: Whether to enable highlighting chart when legend is being hovered.

startAngle.desc: The start angle of gauge chart. The direct right side of circle center is 0 degree, the right above it is 90 degree, the direct left side of it is 180 degree.

clockwise.desc: Whether the scale in gauge chart increases clockwise.

data.desc:
Data array of series, which can be a single data value, like:

[12, 34, 56, 10, 23]

Or, if need extra dimensions for components like visualMap to map to graphic attributes like color, it can also be in the form of array. For example:

[[12, 14], [34, 50], [56, 30], [10, 15], [23, 10]]

In this case, we can assgin the second value in each array item to visualMap component.

More likely, we need to assign name to each data item, in which case each item should be an object:

[{
    // name of date item
    name: 'data1',
    // value of date item is 8
    value: 10
}, {
    name: 'data2',
    value: 20
}]

Each data item can be further customized:

[{
    name: 'data1',
    value: 10
}, {
    // name of data item
    name: 'data2',
    value : 56,
    // user-defined label format that only useful for this data item
    label: {},
    // user-defined special itemStyle that only useful for this data item
    itemStyle:{}
}]

data.title.offsetCenter.desc: The offset position relative to the center of gauge chart. The first item of array is the horizontal offset; the second item of array is the vertical offset. It could be absolute value and also the percentage relative to the radius of gauge chart.

data.title.lineHeight.desc:
Line height of the text fragment.

If lineHeight is not set in rich, lineHeight in parent level will be used. For example:

{
    lineHeight: 56,
    rich: {
        a: {
            // `lineHeight` is not set, then it will be 56
        }
    }
}

data.title.backgroundColor.desc:
Background color of the text fragment.

Can be color string, like '#123234', 'red', 'rgba(0,23,11,0.3)'.

Or image can be used, for example:

backgroundColor: {
    image: 'xxx/xxx.png'
    // It can be URL of a image,
    // or dataURI,
    // or HTMLImageElement,
    // or HTMLCanvasElement.
}

width or height can be specified when using background image, or auto adapted by default.

data.title.borderType.desc:
the text fragment border type.

Possible values are:

  • 'solid'
  • 'dashed'
  • 'dotted'

Since v5.0.0, it can also be a number or a number array to specify the dash array of the line. With borderDashOffset , we can make the line style more flexible.

For example：

{

borderType: [5, 10],

borderDashOffset: 5
}

data.title.borderDashOffset.desc:
Since v5.0.0

To set the line dash offset. With borderType , we can make the line style more flexible.

Refer to MDN lineDashOffset for more details.

data.title.padding.desc:
Padding of the text fragment, for example:

  • padding: [3, 4, 5, 6]: represents padding of [top, right, bottom, left].
  • padding: 4: represents padding: [4, 4, 4, 4].
  • padding: [3, 4]: represents padding: [3, 4, 3, 4].

Notice, width and height specifies the width and height of the content, without padding.

data.title.shadowOffsetX.desc: Shadow X offset of the text block.

data.title.shadowOffsetY.desc: Shadow Y offset of the text block.

data.title.textBorderType.desc:
Stroke line type of the text.

Possible values are:

  • 'solid'
  • 'dashed'
  • 'dotted'

Since v5.0.0, it can also be a number or a number array to specify the dash array of the line. With textBorderDashOffset , we can make the line style more flexible.

For example：

{

textBorderType: [5, 10],

textBorderDashOffset: 5
}

data.title.textBorderDashOffset.desc:
Since v5.0.0

To set the line dash offset. With textBorderType , we can make the line style more flexible.

Refer to MDN lineDashOffset for more details.

data.title.textShadowOffsetX.desc: Shadow X offset of the text itself.

data.title.textShadowOffsetY.desc: Shadow Y offset of the text itself.

data.title.overflow.desc:
Determine how to display the text when it's overflow. Available when width is set.

  • 'truncate' Truncate the text and trailing with ellipsis.
  • 'break' Break by word
  • 'breakAll' Break by character.

data.title.ellipsis.desc:
Ellipsis to be displayed when overflow is set to truncate.

  • 'truncate' Truncate the overflow lines.

data.title.rich.desc:
"Rich text styles" can be defined in this rich property. For example:

label: {
    // Styles defined in 'rich' can be applied to some fragments
    // of text by adding some markers to those fragment, like
    // `{styleName|text content text content}`.
    // `'\n'` is the newline character.
    formatter: [
        '{a|Style "a" is applied to this snippet}'
        '{b|Style "b" is applied to this snippet}This snippet use default style{x|use style "x"}'
    ].join('\n'),

    rich: {
        a: {
            color: 'red',
            lineHeight: 10
        },
        b: {
            backgroundColor: {
                image: 'xxx/xxx.jpg'
            },
            height: 40
        },
        x: {
            fontSize: 18,
            fontFamily: 'Microsoft YaHei',
            borderColor: '#449933',
            borderRadius: 4
        },
        ...
    }
}

For more details, see Rich Text please.

data.title.rich.<style_name>.align.desc:
Horizontal alignment of text, automatic by default.

Options are:

  • 'left'
  • 'center'
  • 'right'

If align is not set in rich, align in parent level will be used. For example:

{
    align: right,
    rich: {
        a: {
            // `align` is not set, then it will be right
        }
    }
}

data.title.rich.<style_name>.verticalAli.desc:
Vertical alignment of text, automatic by default.

Options are:

  • 'top'
  • 'middle'
  • 'bottom'

If verticalAlign is not set in rich, verticalAlign in parent level will be used. For example:

{
    verticalAlign: bottom,
    rich: {
        a: {
            // `verticalAlign` is not set, then it will be bottom
        }
    }
}

data.title.rich.<style_name>.lineHeight.desc:
Line height of the text fragment.

If lineHeight is not set in rich, lineHeight in parent level will be used. For example:

{
    lineHeight: 56,
    rich: {
        a: {
            // `lineHeight` is not set, then it will be 56
        }
    }
}

data.title.rich.<style_name>.backgroundC.desc:
Background color of the text fragment.

Can be color string, like '#123234', 'red', 'rgba(0,23,11,0.3)'.

Or image can be used, for example:

backgroundColor: {
    image: 'xxx/xxx.png'
    // It can be URL of a image,
    // or dataURI,
    // or HTMLImageElement,
    // or HTMLCanvasElement.
}

width or height can be specified when using background image, or auto adapted by default.

data.title.rich.<style_name>.borderType.desc:
the text fragment border type.

Possible values are:

  • 'solid'
  • 'dashed'
  • 'dotted'

Since v5.0.0, it can also be a number or a number array to specify the dash array of the line. With borderDashOffset , we can make the line style more flexible.

For example：

{

borderType: [5, 10],

borderDashOffset: 5

data.title.rich.<style_name>.borderDashO.desc:
Since v5.0.0

To set the line dash offset. With borderType , we can make the line style more flexible.

Refer to MDN lineDashOffset for more details.

data.title.rich.<style_name>.padding.desc:
Padding of the text fragment, for example:

  • padding: [3, 4, 5, 6]: represents padding of [top, right, bottom, left].
  • padding: 4: represents padding: [4, 4, 4, 4].
  • padding: [3, 4]: represents padding: [3, 4, 3, 4].

Notice, width and height specifies the width and height of the content, without padding.

data.title.rich.<style_name>.shadowOffse.desc: Shadow X offset of the text block.
Shadow Y offset of the text block.

data.title.rich.<style_name>.width.desc:
Width of the text block. It is the width of the text by default. In most cases, there is no need to specify it. You may want to use it in some cases like make simple table or using background image (see backgroundColor).

Notice, width and height specifies the width and height of the content, without padding.

width can also be percent string, like '100%', which represents the percent of contentWidth (that is, the width without padding) of its container box. It is based on contentWidth because that each text fragment is layout based on the content box, where it makes no sense that calculating width based on outerWith in prectice.

Notice, width and height only work when rich specified.

data.title.rich.<style_name>.height.desc:
Height of the text block. It is the width of the text by default. You may want to use it in some cases like using background image (see backgroundColor).

Notice, width and height specifies the width and height of the content, without padding.

Notice, width and height only work when rich specified.

data.title.rich.<style_name>.textBorderT.desc:

Possible values are:

  • 'solid'
  • 'dashed'
  • 'dotted'

For example：

data.title.rich.<style_name>.textBorderD.desc:

To set the line dash offset. With textBorderType , we can make the line style more flexible.

Refer to MDN lineDashOffset for more details.

data.title.rich.<style_name>.textShadowO.desc: Shadow X offset of the text itself.
Shadow Y offset of the text itself.

data.title.valueAnimation.desc:
Since v5.0.0

Whether to enable text animation of value change.

data.detail.desc: The detail about gauge chart which is used to show data.

data.detail.color.desc: The text color. Defaults to use the color of section where the numerical value belongs to.

data.detail.lineHeight.desc:

data.detail.valueAnimation.desc:
Since v5.0.0

Whether to enable text animation of value change.

data.detail.offsetCenter.desc: The offset position relative to the center of gauge chart. The first item of array is the horizontal offset; the second item of array is the vertical offset. It could be absolute value and also the percentage relative to the radius of gauge chart.

data.detail.formatter.desc:
Formatter is used to format detail, which supports string template and callback function.

formatter: function (value) {
    return value.toFixed(0);
}

data.itemStyle.color.desc:
color.

Supports setting as solid color using rgb(255,255,255), rgba(255,255,255,1), #fff, etc. Also supports setting as gradient color and pattern fill, see option.color for details

data.itemStyle.borderColor.desc: border color, whose format is similar to that of color.

data.itemStyle.borderWidth.desc:
border width. No border when it is set to be 0.

border width. No border when it is set to be 0.

data.itemStyle.borderType.desc:
border type.

Possible values are:

  • 'solid'
  • 'dashed'
  • 'dotted'

Since v5.0.0, it can also be a number or a number array to specify the dash array of the line. With borderDashOffset , we can make the line style more flexible.

For example：

{

borderType: [5, 10],

borderDashOffset: 5
}

data.itemStyle.borderDashOffset.desc:
Since v5.0.0

To set the line dash offset. With borderType , we can make the line style more flexible.

Refer to MDN lineDashOffset for more details.

data.itemStyle.borderCap.desc:
Since v5.0.0

To specify how to draw the end points of the line. Possible values are:

  • 'butt': The ends of lines are squared off at the endpoints.
  • 'round': The ends of lines are rounded.
  • 'square': The ends of lines are squared off by adding a box with an equal width and half the height of the line's thickness.

Default value is 'butt'. Refer to MDN lineCap for more details.

data.itemStyle.borderJoin.desc:
Since v5.0.0

To determine the shape used to join two line segments where they meet.

Possible values are:

  • 'bevel': Fills an additional triangular area between the common endpoint of connected segments, and the separate outside rectangular corners of each segment.
  • 'round': Rounds off the corners of a shape by filling an additional sector of disc centered at the common endpoint of connected segments. The radius for these rounded corners is equal to the line width.
  • 'miter': Connected segments are joined by extending their outside edges to connect at a single point, with the effect of filling an additional lozenge-shaped area. This setting is affected by the borderMiterLimit property.

Default value is 'bevel'. Refer to MDN lineJoin for more details.

data.itemStyle.borderMiterLimit.desc:
Since v5.0.0

To set the miter limit ratio. Only works when borderJoin is set as miter.

Default value is 10. Negative、0、Infinity and NaN values are ignored.

Refer to MDN miterLimit for more details.

data.itemStyle.shadowBlur.desc:
Size of shadow blur. This attribute should be used along with shadowColor,shadowOffsetX, shadowOffsetY to set shadow to component.

For example:

{
    shadowColor: 'rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.5)',
    shadowBlur: 10
}

data.itemStyle.shadowColor.desc: Shadow color. Support same format as color.

data.itemStyle.shadowOffsetX.desc: Offset distance on the horizontal direction of shadow.

data.itemStyle.shadowOffsetY.desc: Offset distance on the vertical direction of shadow.

data.itemStyle.opacity.desc: Opacity of the component. Supports value from 0 to 1, and the component will not be drawn when set to 0.

data.itemStyle.decal.desc:
The style of the decal pattern. It works only if aria.enabled and aria.decal.show are both set to be true.

If it is set to be 'none', no decal will be used.

data.itemStyle.decal.symbol.desc:
The symbol type of the decal. If it is in the type of string[], it means the symbols are used one by one.

Icon types provided by ECharts includes

'circle', 'rect', 'roundRect', 'triangle', 'diamond', 'pin', 'arrow', 'none'

It can be set to an image with 'image://url' , in which URL is the link to an image, or dataURI of an image.

An image URL example:

'image://http://example.website/a/b.png'

A dataURI example:

'image://data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhEAAQAMQAAORHHOVSKudfOulrSOp3WOyDZu6QdvCchPGolfO0o/XBs/fNwfjZ0frl3/zy7////wAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAACH5BAkAABAALAAAAAAQABAAAAVVICSOZGlCQAosJ6mu7fiyZeKqNKToQGDsM8hBADgUXoGAiqhSvp5QAnQKGIgUhwFUYLCVDFCrKUE1lBavAViFIDlTImbKC5Gm2hB0SlBCBMQiB0UjIQA7'

Icons can be set to arbitrary vector path via 'path://' in ECharts. As compared with a raster image, vector paths prevent jagging and blurring when scaled, and have better control over changing colors. The size of the vector icon will be adapted automatically. Refer to SVG PathData for more information about the format of the path. You may export vector paths from tools like Adobe

For example:

'path://M30.9,53.2C16.8,53.2,5.3,41.7,5.3,27.6S16.8,2,30.9,2C45,2,56.4,13.5,56.4,27.6S45,53.2,30.9,53.2z M30.9,3.5C17.6,3.5,6.8,14.4,6.8,27.6c0,13.3,10.8,24.1,24.101,24.1C44.2,51.7,55,40.9,55,27.6C54.9,14.4,44.1,3.5,30.9,3.5z M36.9,35.8c0,0.601-0.4,1-0.9,1h-1.3c-0.5,0-0.9-0.399-0.9-1V19.5c0-0.6,0.4-1,0.9-1H36c0.5,0,0.9,0.4,0.9,1V35.8z M27.8,35.8 c0,0.601-0.4,1-0.9,1h-1.3c-0.5,0-0.9-0.399-0.9-1V19.5c0-0.6,0.4-1,0.9-1H27c0.5,0,0.9,0.4,0.9,1L27.8,35.8L27.8,35.8z'

data.itemStyle.decal.symbolSize.desc: Range of values: 0 to 1, representing the size of symbol relative to decal.

data.itemStyle.decal.symbolKeepAspect.desc: Whether or not to keep the aspect ratio of the pattern.

data.itemStyle.decal.color.desc: For the color of the decal pattern, it is recommended to use a translucent color, which can be superimposed on the color of the series itself.

data.itemStyle.decal.backgroundColor.desc: The background color of the decal will be over the color of the series itself, under the decal pattern.

data.itemStyle.decal.dashArrayX.desc:
The basic pattern of the decal pattern is an infinite loop in the form of Pattern - Blank - Pattern - Blank - Pattern - Blank both horizontally and vertically, respectively. By setting the length of each pattern and blank, complex pattern effects can be achieved.

dashArrayX controls the horizontal pattern pattern. When its value is of type number or number[], it is similar to SVG stroke-dasharray.

  • If it is of type number, it means that the pattern and the blank space are of this value respectively. For example, 5 means the pattern with width 5 is displayed first, then 5 pixels empty, then the pattern with width 5 is displayed...

  • In the case of number[] type, it means that the pattern and empty space are loops of an array of values. For example: [5, 10, 2, 6] means the pattern is 5 pixels wide, then 10 pixels empty, then the pattern is 2 pixels wide, then 6 pixels empty, then the pattern is 5 pixels wide...

  • If of type (number | number[])[], it means that each row is a loop with an array of values for the pattern and blank space. For example: [10, [2, 5]] means that the first line will be 10 pixels by 10 pixels and empty space, the second line will be 2 pixels by 2 pixels and empty space, and the third line will be 10 pixels by 10 pixels and empty space...

This interface can be better understood with the following examples.

data.itemStyle.decal.dashArrayY.desc:
The basic pattern of the decal pattern is an infinite loop in the form of Pattern - Blank - Pattern - Blank - Pattern - Blank both horizontally and vertically, respectively. By setting the length of each pattern and blank, complex pattern effects can be achieved.

dashArrayY controls the horizontal pattern pattern. Similar to SVG stroke-dasharray.

  • If it is a number type, it means the pattern and the blank are each of this value. For example, 5 means that the pattern with a height of 5 is displayed first, then 5 pixels empty, then the pattern with a height of 5 is displayed...

  • In the case of number[] type, it means that the pattern and empty space are loops of sequential array values. For example: [5, 10, 2, 6] means the pattern is 5 pixels high, then 10 pixels empty, then the pattern is 2 pixels high, then 6 pixels empty, then the pattern is 5 pixels high...

This interface can be better understood with the following examples.

data.itemStyle.decal.rotation.desc: The overall rotation angle (in radians) of the pattern, in the range from `-Math.

data.itemStyle.decal.maxTileWidth.desc: The upper limit of the width of the generated pattern before it is duplicated. Usually this value is not necessary, but you can try to increase it if you notice discontinuous seams in the pattern when it repeats.

data.itemStyle.decal.maxTileHeight.desc: The upper limit of the height of the generated pattern before it repeats. This value is usually not necessary to set, but you can try to increase it if you find that the pattern has discontinuous seams when it is repeated.

min.desc: The minimum data value which map to minAngle.

max.desc: The maximum data value which map to maxAngle.

splitNumber.desc: The number of split segments of gauge chart scale.

axisLine.desc: The related configuration about the axis line of gauge chart.

axisLine.show.desc: Whether to show the axis line of gauge chart.

axisLine.roundCap.desc:
Since v5.0.0

Whether to add round caps at the end.

axisLine.lineStyle.desc: The style of the axis line of gauge chart.

axisLine.lineStyle.color.desc:
The axis line of gauge chart can be divided to several segments in different colors. The end position and color of each segment can be expressed by an array.

Default value:

[[1, '#E6EBF8']]

Note: The value of color[i][0] means the percentage of the axis line of the gauge chart's segments, which should be between 0 and 1, and color[i][1] is the corresponding color.

color: [
    [0.1, 'red'], // 0~10% is red
    [0.2, 'green'], // 10~20% is green
    [0.3, 'blue'], // 20~30% is blue
    // ...
]

axisLine.lineStyle.shadowBlur.desc:
Size of shadow blur. This attribute should be used along with shadowColor,shadowOffsetX, shadowOffsetY to set shadow to component.

For example:

{
    shadowColor: 'rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.5)',
    shadowBlur: 10
}

axisLine.lineStyle.shadowColor.desc: Shadow color. Support same format as color.

axisLine.lineStyle.shadowOffsetX.desc: Offset distance on the horizontal direction of shadow.

axisLine.lineStyle.shadowOffsetY.desc: Offset distance on the vertical direction of shadow.

axisLine.lineStyle.opacity.desc: Opacity of the component. Supports value from 0 to 1, and the component will not be drawn when set to 0.

progress.show.desc: Whether to show the progress of gauge chart.

progress.overlap.desc: Whether the progress overlaps when there are multiple groups of data.

progress.roundCap.desc: Whether to add round caps at the end

progress.itemStyle.color.desc:
color.

Supports setting as solid color using rgb(255,255,255), rgba(255,255,255,1), #fff, etc. Also supports setting as gradient color and pattern fill, see option.color for details

progress.itemStyle.borderColor.desc: border color, whose format is similar to that of color.

progress.itemStyle.borderWidth.desc:
border width. No border when it is set to be 0.

border width. No border when it is set to be 0.

progress.itemStyle.borderType.desc:
border type.

Possible values are:

  • 'solid'
  • 'dashed'
  • 'dotted'

Since v5.0.0, it can also be a number or a number array to specify the dash array of the line. With borderDashOffset , we can make the line style more flexible.

For example：

{

borderType: [5, 10],

borderDashOffset: 5
}

progress.itemStyle.borderDashOffset.desc:
Since v5.0.0

To set the line dash offset. With borderType , we can make the line style more flexible.

Refer to MDN lineDashOffset for more details.

progress.itemStyle.borderCap.desc:
Since v5.0.0

To specify how to draw the end points of the line. Possible values are:

  • 'butt': The ends of lines are squared off at the endpoints.
  • 'round': The ends of lines are rounded.
  • 'square': The ends of lines are squared off by adding a box with an equal width and half the height of the line's thickness.

Default value is 'butt'. Refer to MDN lineCap for more details.

progress.itemStyle.borderJoin.desc:
Since v5.0.0

To determine the shape used to join two line segments where they meet.

Possible values are:

  • 'bevel': Fills an additional triangular area between the common endpoint of connected segments, and the separate outside rectangular corners of each segment.
  • 'round': Rounds off the corners of a shape by filling an additional sector of disc centered at the common endpoint of connected segments. The radius for these rounded corners is equal to the line width.
  • 'miter': Connected segments are joined by extending their outside edges to connect at a single point, with the effect of filling an additional lozenge-shaped area. This setting is affected by the borderMiterLimit property.

Default value is 'bevel'. Refer to MDN lineJoin for more details.

progress.itemStyle.borderMiterLimit.desc:
Since v5.0.0

To set the miter limit ratio. Only works when borderJoin is set as miter.

Default value is 10. Negative、0、Infinity and NaN values are ignored.

Refer to MDN miterLimit for more details.

progress.itemStyle.shadowBlur.desc:
Size of shadow blur. This attribute should be used along with shadowColor,shadowOffsetX, shadowOffsetY to set shadow to component.

For example:

{
    shadowColor: 'rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.5)',
    shadowBlur: 10
}

progress.itemStyle.shadowOffsetY.desc: Offset distance on the vertical direction of shadow.

progress.itemStyle.opacity.desc: Opacity of the component. Supports value from 0 to 1, and the component will not be drawn when set to 0.

axisTick.lineStyle.shadowOffsetX.desc: Offset distance on the horizontal direction of shadow.

axisTick.lineStyle.shadowOffsetY.desc: Offset distance on the vertical direction of shadow.

axisTick.lineStyle.opacity.desc: Opacity of the component. Supports value from 0 to 1, and the component will not be drawn when set to 0.

axisLabel.distance.desc: The distance between the label and tick line.

axisLabel.rotate.desc:
Since v5.4.0

If it is number type, then is stands for rotation, from -90 degrees to 90 degrees, and positive values stand for counterclockwise.

Besides, it can be string 'radial', standing for radial rotation; or 'tangential', standing for tangential rotation.

If no rotation is wanted, it can be set to 0.

axisLabel.formatter.desc:
The content formatter of scale label, which supports both string template and callback function. Example:

// use string template. the template variable {value} represent the default label text
formatter: '{value} kg'

// use function callback. the function parameters are scale values.
formatter: function (value) {
    return value + 'km/h';
}

axisLabel.lineHeight.desc:
Line height of the text fragment.

If lineHeight is not set in rich, lineHeight in parent level will be used. For example:

{
    lineHeight: 56,
    rich: {
        a: {
            // `lineHeight` is not set, then it will be 56
        }
    }
}

axisLabel.backgroundColor.desc:
Background color of the text fragment.

Can be color string, like '#123234', 'red', 'rgba(0,23,11,0.3)'.

Or image can be used, for example:

backgroundColor: {
    image: 'xxx/xxx.png'
    // It can be URL of a image,
    // or dataURI,
    // or HTMLImageElement,
    // or HTMLCanvasElement.
}

width or height can be specified when using background image, or auto adapted by default.

axisLabel.borderType.desc:
the text fragment border type.

Possible values are:

  • 'solid'
  • 'dashed'
  • 'dotted'

Since v5.0.0, it can also be a number or a number array to specify the dash array of the line. With borderDashOffset , we can make the line style more flexible.

For example：

{

borderType: [5, 10],

borderDashOffset: 5
}

axisLabel.borderDashOffset.desc:
Since v5.0.0

To set the line dash offset. With borderType , we can make the line style more flexible.

Refer to MDN lineDashOffset for more details.

axisLabel.padding.desc:
Padding of the text fragment, for example:

  • padding: [3, 4, 5, 6]: represents padding of [top, right, bottom, left].
  • padding: 4: represents padding: [4, 4, 4, 4].
  • padding: [3, 4]: represents padding: [3, 4, 3, 4].

Notice, width and height specifies the width and height of the content, without padding.

axisLabel.shadowOffsetX.desc: Shadow X offset of the text block.

axisLabel.shadowOffsetY.desc: Shadow Y offset of the text block.

axisLabel.textBorderType.desc:
Stroke line type of the text.

Possible values are:

  • 'solid'
  • 'dashed'
  • 'dotted'

Since v5.0.0, it can also be a number or a number array to specify the dash array of the line. With textBorderDashOffset , we can make the line style more flexible.

For example：

{

textBorderType: [5, 10],

textBorderDashOffset: 5
}

axisLabel.textBorderDashOffset.desc:
Since v5.0.0

To set the line dash offset. With textBorderType , we can make the line style more flexible.

Refer to MDN lineDashOffset for more details.

axisLabel.textShadowOffsetX.desc: Shadow X offset of the text itself.

axisLabel.textShadowOffsetY.desc: Shadow Y offset of the text itself.

axisLabel.overflow.desc:
Determine how to display the text when it's overflow. Available when width is set.

  • 'truncate' Truncate the text and trailing with ellipsis.
  • 'break' Break by word
  • 'breakAll' Break by character.

axisLabel.ellipsis.desc:
Ellipsis to be displayed when overflow is set to truncate.

  • 'truncate' Truncate the overflow lines.

axisLabel.rich.desc:
"Rich text styles" can be defined in this rich property. For example:

label: {
    // Styles defined in 'rich' can be applied to some fragments
    // of text by adding some markers to those fragment, like
    // `{styleName|text content text content}`.
    // `'\n'` is the newline character.
    formatter: [
        '{a|Style "a" is applied to this snippet}'
        '{b|Style "b" is applied to this snippet}This snippet use default style{x|use style "x"}'
    ].join('\n'),

    rich: {
        a: {
            color: 'red',
            lineHeight: 10
        },
        b: {
            backgroundColor: {
                image: 'xxx/xxx.jpg'
            },
            height: 40
        },
        x: {
            fontSize: 18,
            fontFamily: 'Microsoft YaHei',
            borderColor: '#449933',
            borderRadius: 4
        },
        ...
    }
}

For more details, see Rich Text please.

axisLabel.rich.<style_name>.align.desc:
Horizontal alignment of text, automatic by default.

Options are:

  • 'left'
  • 'center'
  • 'right'

If align is not set in rich, align in parent level will be used. For example:

{
    align: right,
    rich: {
        a: {
            // `align` is not set, then it will be right
        }
    }
}

axisLabel.rich.<style_name>.verticalAlig.desc:
Vertical alignment of text, automatic by default.

Options are:

  • 'top'
  • 'middle'
  • 'bottom'

If verticalAlign is not set in rich, verticalAlign in parent level will be used. For example:

{
    verticalAlign: bottom,
    rich: {
        a: {
            // `verticalAlign` is not set, then it will be bottom
        }
    }
}

axisLabel.rich.<style_name>.lineHeight.desc:
Line height of the text fragment.

If lineHeight is not set in rich, lineHeight in parent level will be used. For example:

{
    lineHeight: 56,
    rich: {
        a: {
            // `lineHeight` is not set, then it will be 56
        }
    }
}

axisLabel.rich.<style_name>.backgroundCo.desc:
Background color of the text fragment.

Can be color string, like '#123234', 'red', 'rgba(0,23,11,0.3)'.

Or image can be used, for example:

backgroundColor: {
    image: 'xxx/xxx.png'
    // It can be URL of a image,
    // or dataURI,
    // or HTMLImageElement,
    // or HTMLCanvasElement.
}

width or height can be specified when using background image, or auto adapted by default.

axisLabel.rich.<style_name>.borderType.desc:
the text fragment border type.

Possible values are:

  • 'solid'
  • 'dashed'
  • 'dotted'

Since v5.0.0, it can also be a number or a number array to specify the dash array of the line. With borderDashOffset , we can make the line style more flexible.

For example：

{

borderType: [5, 10],

borderDashOffset: 5
}

axisLabel.rich.<style_name>.borderDashOf.desc:
Since v5.0.0

To set the line dash offset. With borderType , we can make the line style more flexible.

Refer to MDN lineDashOffset for more details.

axisLabel.rich.<style_name>.padding.desc:
Padding of the text fragment, for example:

  • padding: [3, 4, 5, 6]: represents padding of [top, right, bottom, left].
  • padding: 4: represents padding: [4, 4, 4, 4].
  • padding: [3, 4]: represents padding: [3, 4, 3, 4].

Notice, width and height specifies the width and height of the content, without padding.

axisLabel.rich.<style_name>.shadowOffset.desc: Shadow X offset of the text block.
Shadow Y offset of the text block.

axisLabel.rich.<style_name>.width.desc:
Width of the text block. It is the width of the text by default. In most cases, there is no need to specify it. You may want to use it in some cases like make simple table or using background image (see backgroundColor).

Notice, width and height specifies the width and height of the content, without padding.

width can also be percent string, like '100%', which represents the percent of contentWidth (that is, the width without padding) of its container box. It is based on contentWidth because that each text fragment is layout based on the content box, where it makes no sense that calculating width based on outerWith in prectice.

Notice, width and height only work when rich specified.

axisLabel.rich.<style_name>.height.desc:
Height of the text block. It is the width of the text by default. You may want to use it in some cases like using background image (see backgroundColor).

Notice, width and height specifies the width and height of the content, without padding.

Notice, width and height only work when rich specified.

Whether to show the pointer above detail and title.

pointer.icon.desc:
Since v5.0

Icon types provided by ECharts includes

'circle', 'rect', 'roundRect', 'triangle', 'diamond', 'pin', 'arrow', 'none'

It can be set to an image with 'image://url' , in which URL is the link to an image, or dataURI of an image.

An image URL example:

'image://http://example.website/a/b.png'

A dataURI example:

'image://data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhEAAQAMQAAORHHOVSKudfOulrSOp3WOyDZu6QdvCchPGolfO0o/XBs/fNwfjZ0frl3/zy7////wAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAACH5BAkAABAALAAAAAAQABAAAAVVICSOZGlCQAosJ6mu7fiyZeKqNKToQGDsM8hBADgUXoGAiqhSvp5QAnQKGIgUhwFUYLCVDFCrKUE1lBavAViFIDlTImbKC5Gm2hB0SlBCBMQiB0UjIQA7'

Icons can be set to arbitrary vector path via 'path://' in ECharts. As compared with a raster image, vector paths prevent jagging and blurring when scaled, and have better control over changing colors. The size of the vector icon will be adapted automatically. Refer to SVG PathData for more information about the format of the path. You may export vector paths from tools like Adobe

For example:

'path://M30.9,53.2C16.8,53.2,5.3,41.7,5.3,27.6S16.8,2,30.9,2C45,2,56.4,13.5,56.4,27.6S45,53.2,30.9,53.2z M30.9,3.5C17.6,3.5,6.8,14.4,6.8,27.6c0,13.3,10.8,24.1,24.101,24.1C44.2,51.7,55,40.9,55,27.6C54.9,14.4,44.1,3.5,30.9,3.5z M36.9,35.8c0,0.601-0.4,1-0.9,1h-1.3c-0.5,0-0.9-0.399-0.9-1V19.5c0-0.6,0.4-1,0.9-1H36c0.5,0,0.9,0.4,0.9,1V35.8z M27.8,35.8 c0,0.601-0.4,1-0.9,1h-1.3c-0.5,0-0.9-0.399-0.9-1V19.5c0-0.6,0.4-1,0.9-1H27c0.5,0,0.9,0.4,0.9,1L27.8,35.8L27.8,35.8z'

pointer.itemStyle.shadowBlur.desc:
Size of shadow blur. This attribute should be used along with shadowColor,shadowOffsetX, shadowOffsetY to set shadow to component.

For example:

{
    shadowColor: 'rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.5)',
    shadowBlur: 10
}

pointer.itemStyle.shadowColor.desc: Shadow color. Support same format as color.

pointer.itemStyle.shadowOffsetX.desc: Offset distance on the horizontal direction of shadow.

pointer.itemStyle.shadowOffsetY.desc: Offset distance on the vertical direction of shadow.

pointer.itemStyle.opacity.desc: Opacity of the component. Supports value from 0 to 1, and the component will not be drawn when set to 0.

anchor.desc:
Since v5.0

The fixed point of a pointer in a dial.

anchor.showAbove.desc: Whether the anchor is showed above the pointer.

anchor.icon.desc:
Icon types provided by ECharts includes

'circle', 'rect', 'roundRect', 'triangle', 'diamond', 'pin', 'arrow', 'none'

It can be set to an image with 'image://url' , in which URL is the link to an image, or dataURI of an image.

An image URL example:

'image://http://example.website/a/b.png'

A dataURI example:

'image://data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhEAAQAMQAAORHHOVSKudfOulrSOp3WOyDZu6QdvCchPGolfO0o/XBs/fNwfjZ0frl3/zy7////wAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAACH5BAkAABAALAAAAAAQABAAAAVVICSOZGlCQAosJ6mu7fiyZeKqNKToQGDsM8hBADgUXoGAiqhSvp5QAnQKGIgUhwFUYLCVDFCrKUE1lBavAViFIDlTImbKC5Gm2hB0SlBCBMQiB0UjIQA7'

Icons can be set to arbitrary vector path via 'path://' in ECharts. As compared with a raster image, vector paths prevent jagging and blurring when scaled, and have better control over changing colors. The size of the vector icon will be adapted automatically. Refer to SVG PathData for more information about the format of the path. You may export vector paths from tools like Adobe

For example:

'path://M30.9,53.2C16.8,53.2,5.3,41.7,5.3,27.6S16.8,2,30.9,2C45,2,56.4,13.5,56.4,27.6S45,53.2,30.9,53.2z M30.9,3.5C17.6,3.5,6.8,14.4,6.8,27.6c0,13.3,10.8,24.1,24.101,24.1C44.2,51.7,55,40.9,55,27.6C54.9,14.4,44.1,3.5,30.9,3.5z M36.9,35.8c0,0.601-0.4,1-0.9,1h-1.3c-0.5,0-0.9-0.399-0.9-1V19.5c0-0.6,0.4-1,0.9-1H36c0.5,0,0.9,0.4,0.9,1V35.8z M27.8,35.8 c0,0.601-0.4,1-0.9,1h-1.3c-0.5,0-0.9-0.399-0.9-1V19.5c0-0.6,0.4-1,0.9-1H27c0.5,0,0.9,0.4,0.9,1L27.8,35.8L27.8,35.8z'

anchor.keepAspect.desc: Whether to keep aspect for icons in the form of path://.

color.

Supports setting as solid color using rgb(255,255,255), rgba(255,255,255,1), #fff, etc. Also supports setting as gradient color and pattern fill, see option.color for details

anchor.itemStyle.borderWidth.desc:
border width. No border when it is set to be 0.

border width. No border when it is set to be 0.

anchor.itemStyle.borderType.desc:
border type.

Possible values are:

  • 'solid'
  • 'dashed'
  • 'dotted'

Since v5.0.0, it can also be a number or a number array to specify the dash array of the line. With borderDashOffset , we can make the line style more flexible.

For example：

{

borderType: [5, 10],

borderDashOffset: 5
}

anchor.itemStyle.borderDashOffset.desc:
Since v5.0.0

To set the line dash offset. With borderType , we can make the line style more flexible.

Refer to MDN lineDashOffset for more details.

anchor.itemStyle.borderCap.desc:
Since v5.0.0

To specify how to draw the end points of the line. Possible values are:

  • 'butt': The ends of lines are squared off at the endpoints.
  • 'round': The ends of lines are rounded.
  • 'square': The ends of lines are squared off by adding a box with an equal width and half the height of the line's thickness.

Default value is 'butt'. Refer to MDN lineCap for more details.

anchor.itemStyle.borderJoin.desc:
Since v5.0.0

To determine the shape used to join two line segments where they meet.

Possible values are:

  • 'bevel': Fills an additional triangular area between the common endpoint of connected segments, and the separate outside rectangular corners of each segment.
  • 'round': Rounds off the corners of a shape by filling an additional sector of disc centered at the common endpoint of connected segments. The radius for these rounded corners is equal to the line width.
  • 'miter': Connected segments are joined by extending their outside edges to connect at a single point, with the effect of filling an additional lozenge-shaped area. This setting is affected by the borderMiterLimit property.

Default value is 'bevel'. Refer to MDN lineJoin for more details.

anchor.itemStyle.borderMiterLimit.desc:
Since v5.0.0

To set the miter limit ratio. Only works when borderJoin is set as miter.

Default value is 10. Negative、0、Infinity and NaN values are ignored.

Refer to MDN miterLimit for more details.

    shadowBlur: 10
}

itemStyle.decal.desc:
The style of the decal pattern. It works only if aria.enabled and aria.decal.show are both set to be true.

If it is set to be 'none', no decal will be used.

itemStyle.decal.symbol.desc:
The symbol type of the decal. If it is in the type of string[], it means the symbols are used one by one.

Icon types provided by ECharts includes

'circle', 'rect', 'roundRect', 'triangle', 'diamond', 'pin', 'arrow', 'none'

It can be set to an image with 'image://url' , in which URL is the link to an image, or dataURI of an image.

An image URL example:

'image://http://example.website/a/b.png'

A dataURI example:

'image://data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhEAAQAMQAAORHHOVSKudfOulrSOp3WOyDZu6QdvCchPGolfO0o/XBs/fNwfjZ0frl3/zy7////wAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAACH5BAkAABAALAAAAAAQABAAAAVVICSOZGlCQAosJ6mu7fiyZeKqNKToQGDsM8hBADgUXoGAiqhSvp5QAnQKGIgUhwFUYLCVDFCrKUE1lBavAViFIDlTImbKC5Gm2hB0SlBCBMQiB0UjIQA7'

Icons can be set to arbitrary vector path via 'path://' in ECharts. As compared with a raster image, vector paths prevent jagging and blurring when scaled, and have better control over changing colors. The size of the vector icon will be adapted automatically. Refer to SVG PathData for more information about the format of the path. You may export vector paths from tools like Adobe

For example:

'path://M30.9,53.2C16.8,53.2,5.3,41.7,5.3,27.6S16.8,2,30.9,2C45,2,56.4,13.5,56.4,27.6S45,53.2,30.9,53.2z M30.9,3.5C17.6,3.5,6.8,14.4,6.8,27.6c0,13.3,10.8,24.1,24.101,24.1C44.2,51.7,55,40.9,55,27.6C54.9,14.4,44.1,3.5,30.9,3.5z M36.9,35.8c0,0.601-0.4,1-0.9,1h-1.3c-0.5,0-0.9-0.399-0.9-1V19.5c0-0.6,0.4-1,0.9-1H36c0.5,0,0.9,0.4,0.9,1V35.8z M27.8,35.8 c0,0.601-0.4,1-0.9,1h-1.3c-0.5,0-0.9-0.399-0.9-1V19.5c0-0.6,0.4-1,0.9-1H27c0.5,0,0.9,0.4,0.9,1L27.8,35.8L27.8,35.8z'

itemStyle.decal.symbolSize.desc: Range of values: 0 to 1, representing the size of symbol relative to decal.

itemStyle.decal.symbolKeepAspect.desc: Whether or not to keep the aspect ratio of the pattern.

itemStyle.decal.color.desc: For the color of the decal pattern, it is recommended to use a translucent color, which can be superimposed on the color of the series itself.

itemStyle.decal.backgroundColor.desc: The background color of the decal will be over the color of the series itself, under the decal pattern.

itemStyle.decal.dashArrayX.desc:
The basic pattern of the decal pattern is an infinite loop in the form of Pattern - Blank - Pattern - Blank - Pattern - Blank both horizontally and vertically, respectively. By setting the length of each pattern and blank, complex pattern effects can be achieved.

dashArrayX controls the horizontal pattern pattern. When its value is of type number or number[], it is similar to SVG stroke-dasharray.

  • If it is of type number, it means that the pattern and the blank space are of this value respectively. For example, 5 means the pattern with width 5 is displayed first, then 5 pixels empty, then the pattern with width 5 is displayed...

  • In the case of number[] type, it means that the pattern and empty space are loops of an array of values. For example: [5, 10, 2, 6] means the pattern is 5 pixels wide, then 10 pixels empty, then the pattern is 2 pixels wide, then 6 pixels empty, then the pattern is 5 pixels wide...

  • If of type (number | number[])[], it means that each row is a loop with an array of values for the pattern and blank space. For example: [10, [2, 5]] means that the first line will be 10 pixels by 10 pixels and empty space, the second line will be 2 pixels by 2 pixels and empty space, and the third line will be 10 pixels by 10 pixels and empty space...

This interface can be better understood with the following examples.

itemStyle.decal.dashArrayY.desc:
The basic pattern of the decal pattern is an infinite loop in the form of Pattern - Blank - Pattern - Blank - Pattern - Blank both horizontally and vertically, respectively. By setting the length of each pattern and blank, complex pattern effects can be achieved.

dashArrayY controls the horizontal pattern pattern. Similar to SVG stroke-dasharray.

  • If it is a number type, it means the pattern and the blank are each of this value. For example, 5 means that the pattern with a height of 5 is displayed first, then 5 pixels empty, then the pattern with a height of 5 is displayed...

  • In the case of number[] type, it means that the pattern and empty space are loops of sequential array values. For example: [5, 10, 2, 6] means the pattern is 5 pixels high, then 10 pixels empty, then the pattern is 2 pixels high, then 6 pixels empty, then the pattern is 5 pixels high...

This interface can be better understood with the following examples.

itemStyle.decal.rotation.desc: The overall rotation angle (in radians) of the pattern, in the range from `-Math.

itemStyle.decal.maxTileWidth.desc: The upper limit of the width of the generated pattern before it is duplicated. Usually this value is not necessary, but you can try to increase it if you notice discontinuous seams in the pattern when it repeats.

itemStyle.decal.maxTileHeight.desc: The upper limit of the height of the generated pattern before it repeats. This value is usually not necessary to set, but you can try to increase it if you find that the pattern has discontinuous seams when it is repeated.

emphasis.disabled.desc:
Since v5.3.0

Whether to disable the emphasis state.

When emphasis state is disabled. There will be no highlight effect when the mouse hovered the element, tooltip is triggered, or the legend is hovered. It can be used to improve interaction fluency when there are massive graphic elements.

emphasis.itemStyle.color.desc:
color. Since v5.2.0, it can be set to 'inherit' in the emphasis state to disable color highlight.

Supports setting as solid color using rgb(255,255,255), rgba(255,255,255,1), #fff, etc. Also supports setting as gradient color and pattern fill, see option.color for details

emphasis.itemStyle.shadowOffsetX.desc: Offset distance on the horizontal direction of shadow.

title.offsetCenter.desc: The offset position relative to the center of gauge chart. The first item of array is the horizontal offset; the second item of array is the vertical offset. It could be absolute value and also the percentage relative to the radius of gauge chart.

title.lineHeight.desc:
Line height of the text fragment.

If lineHeight is not set in rich, lineHeight in parent level will be used. For example:

{
    lineHeight: 56,
    rich: {
        a: {
            // `lineHeight` is not set, then it will be 56
        }
    }
}

title.backgroundColor.desc:
Background color of the text fragment.

Can be color string, like '#123234', 'red', 'rgba(0,23,11,0.3)'.

Or image can be used, for example:

backgroundColor: {
    image: 'xxx/xxx.png'
    // It can be URL of a image,
    // or dataURI,
    // or HTMLImageElement,
    // or HTMLCanvasElement.
}

width or height can be specified when using background image, or auto adapted by default.

title.borderType.desc:
the text fragment border type.

Possible values are:

  • 'solid'
  • 'dashed'
  • 'dotted'

Since v5.0.0, it can also be a number or a number array to specify the dash array of the line. With borderDashOffset , we can make the line style more flexible.

For example：

{

borderType: [5, 10],

borderDashOffset: 5
}

title.borderDashOffset.desc:
Since v5.0.0

To set the line dash offset. With borderType , we can make the line style more flexible.

Refer to MDN lineDashOffset for more details.

title.padding.desc:
Padding of the text fragment, for example:

  • padding: [3, 4, 5, 6]: represents padding of [top, right, bottom, left].
  • padding: 4: represents padding: [4, 4, 4, 4].
  • padding: [3, 4]: represents padding: [3, 4, 3, 4].

Notice, width and height specifies the width and height of the content, without padding.

title.shadowOffsetX.desc: Shadow X offset of the text block.

title.shadowOffsetY.desc: Shadow Y offset of the text block.

title.textBorderType.desc:
Stroke line type of the text.

Possible values are:

  • 'solid'
  • 'dashed'
  • 'dotted'

Since v5.0.0, it can also be a number or a number array to specify the dash array of the line. With textBorderDashOffset , we can make the line style more flexible.

For example：

{

textBorderType: [5, 10],

textBorderDashOffset: 5
}

title.textBorderDashOffset.desc:
Since v5.0.0

To set the line dash offset. With textBorderType , we can make the line style more flexible.

Refer to MDN lineDashOffset for more details.

title.textShadowOffsetX.desc: Shadow X offset of the text itself.

title.textShadowOffsetY.desc: Shadow Y offset of the text itself.

title.overflow.desc:
Determine how to display the text when it's overflow. Available when width is set.

  • 'truncate' Truncate the text and trailing with ellipsis.
  • 'break' Break by word
  • 'breakAll' Break by character.

title.ellipsis.desc:
Ellipsis to be displayed when overflow is set to truncate.

  • 'truncate' Truncate the overflow lines.

title.rich.desc:
"Rich text styles" can be defined in this rich property. For example:

label: {
    // Styles defined in 'rich' can be applied to some fragments
    // of text by adding some markers to those fragment, like
    // `{styleName|text content text content}`.
    // `'\n'` is the newline character.
    formatter: [
        '{a|Style "a" is applied to this snippet}'
        '{b|Style "b" is applied to this snippet}This snippet use default style{x|use style "x"}'
    ].join('\n'),

    rich: {
        a: {
            color: 'red',
            lineHeight: 10
        },
        b: {
            backgroundColor: {
                image: 'xxx/xxx.jpg'
            },
            height: 40
        },
        x: {
            fontSize: 18,
            fontFamily: 'Microsoft YaHei',
            borderColor: '#449933',
            borderRadius: 4
        },
        ...
    }
}

For more details, see Rich Text please.

title.rich.<style_name>.align.desc:
Horizontal alignment of text, automatic by default.

Options are:

  • 'left'
  • 'center'
  • 'right'

If align is not set in rich, align in parent level will be used. For example:

{
    align: right,
    rich: {
        a: {
            // `align` is not set, then it will be right
        }
    }
}

title.rich.<style_name>.verticalAlign.desc:
Vertical alignment of text, automatic by default.

Options are:

  • 'top'
  • 'middle'
  • 'bottom'

If verticalAlign is not set in rich, verticalAlign in parent level will be used. For example:

{
    verticalAlign: bottom,
    rich: {
        a: {
            // `verticalAlign` is not set, then it will be bottom
        }
    }
}

title.rich.<style_name>.lineHeight.desc:
Line height of the text fragment.

If lineHeight is not set in rich, lineHeight in parent level will be used. For example:

{
    lineHeight: 56,
    rich: {
        a: {
            // `lineHeight` is not set, then it will be 56
        }
    }
}

title.rich.<style_name>.backgroundColor.desc:
Background color of the text fragment.

Can be color string, like '#123234', 'red', 'rgba(0,23,11,0.3)'.

Or image can be used, for example:

backgroundColor: {
    image: 'xxx/xxx.png'
    // It can be URL of a image,
    // or dataURI,
    // or HTMLImageElement,
    // or HTMLCanvasElement.
}

width or height can be specified when using background image, or auto adapted by default.

title.rich.<style_name>.borderType.desc:
the text fragment border type.

Possible values are:

  • 'solid'
  • 'dashed'
  • 'dotted'

Since v5.0.0, it can also be a number or a number array to specify the dash array of the line. With borderDashOffset , we can make the line style more flexible.

For example：

{

borderType: [5, 10],

borderDashOffset: 5
}

title.rich.<style_name>.borderDashOffset.desc:
Since v5.0.0

To set the line dash offset. With borderType , we can make the line style more flexible.

Refer to MDN lineDashOffset for more details.

title.rich.<style_name>.padding.desc:
Padding of the text fragment, for example:

  • padding: [3, 4, 5, 6]: represents padding of [top, right, bottom, left].
  • padding: 4: represents padding: [4, 4, 4, 4].
  • padding: [3, 4]: represents padding: [3, 4, 3, 4].

Notice, width and height specifies the width and height of the content, without padding.

title.rich.<style_name>.shadowOffsetX.desc: Shadow X offset of the text block.

title.rich.<style_name>.shadowOffsetY.desc: Shadow Y offset of the text block.

title.rich.<style_name>.width.desc:
Width of the text block. It is the width of the text by default. In most cases, there is no need to specify it. You may want to use it in some cases like make simple table or using background image (see backgroundColor).

Notice, width and height specifies the width and height of the content, without padding.

width can also be percent string, like '100%', which represents the percent of contentWidth (that is, the width without padding) of its container box. It is based on contentWidth because that each text fragment is layout based on the content box, where it makes no sense that calculating width based on outerWith in prectice.

Notice, width and height only work when rich specified.

title.rich.<style_name>.height.desc:
Height of the text block. It is the width of the text by default. You may want to use it in some cases like using background image (see backgroundColor).

Notice, width and height specifies the width and height of the content, without padding.

Notice, width and height only work when rich specified.

  • 'solid'
  • 'dashed'
  • 'dotted'

To set the line dash offset. With textBorderType , we can make the line style more flexible.

title.rich.<style_name>.textShadowOffset.desc: Shadow X offset of the text itself.
Shadow Y offset of the text itself.

Since v5.0.0

Whether to enable text animation of value change.

detail.desc: The detail about gauge chart which is used to show data.

detail.color.desc: The text color. Defaults to use the color of section where the numerical value belongs to.

detail.lineHeight.desc:
Line height of the text fragment.

If lineHeight is not set in rich, lineHeight in parent level will be used. For example:

detail.rich.desc:
"Rich text styles" can be defined in this rich property. For example:

label: {
    // Styles defined in 'rich' can be applied to some fragments
    // of text by adding some markers to those fragment, like
    // `{styleName|text content text content}`.
    // `'\n'` is the newline character.
    formatter: [
        '{a|Style "a" is applied to this snippet}'
        '{b|Style "b" is applied to this snippet}This snippet use default style{x|use style "x"}'
    ].join('\n'),

    rich: {
        a: {
            color: 'red',
            lineHeight: 10
        },
        b: {
            backgroundColor: {
                image: 'xxx/xxx.jpg'
            },
            height: 40
        },
        x: {
            fontSize: 18,
            fontFamily: 'Microsoft YaHei',
            borderColor: '#449933',
            borderRadius: 4
        },
        ...
    }
}

For more details, see Rich Text please.

detail.rich.<style_name>.width.desc:
Width of the text block. It is the width of the text by default. In most cases, there is no need to specify it. You may want to use it in some cases like make simple table or using background image (see backgroundColor).

Notice, width and height specifies the width and height of the content, without padding.

width can also be percent string, like '100%', which represents the percent of contentWidth (that is, the width without padding) of its container box. It is based on contentWidth because that each text fragment is layout based on the content box, where it makes no sense that calculating width based on outerWith in prectice.

Notice, width and height only work when rich specified.

detail.valueAnimation.desc:
Since v5.0.0

Whether to enable text animation of value change.

detail.offsetCenter.desc: The offset position relative to the center of gauge chart. The first item of array is the horizontal offset; the second item of array is the vertical offset. It could be absolute value and also the percentage relative to the radius of gauge chart.

detail.formatter.desc:
Formatter is used to format detail, which supports string template and callback function.

formatter: function (value) {
    return value.toFixed(0);
}

markPoint.symbol.desc:
Symbol of .

Icon types provided by ECharts includes

'circle', 'rect', 'roundRect', 'triangle', 'diamond', 'pin', 'arrow', 'none'

It can be set to an image with 'image://url' , in which URL is the link to an image, or dataURI of an image.

An image URL example:

'image://http://example.website/a/b.png'

A dataURI example:

'image://data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhEAAQAMQAAORHHOVSKudfOulrSOp3WOyDZu6QdvCchPGolfO0o/XBs/fNwfjZ0frl3/zy7////wAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAACH5BAkAABAALAAAAAAQABAAAAVVICSOZGlCQAosJ6mu7fiyZeKqNKToQGDsM8hBADgUXoGAiqhSvp5QAnQKGIgUhwFUYLCVDFCrKUE1lBavAViFIDlTImbKC5Gm2hB0SlBCBMQiB0UjIQA7'

Icons can be set to arbitrary vector path via 'path://' in ECharts. As compared with a raster image, vector paths prevent jagging and blurring when scaled, and have better control over changing colors. The size of the vector icon will be adapted automatically. Refer to SVG PathData for more information about the format of the path. You may export vector paths from tools like Adobe

For example:

'path://M30.9,53.2C16.8,53.2,5.3,41.7,5.3,27.6S16.8,2,30.9,2C45,2,56.4,13.5,56.4,27.6S45,53.2,30.9,53.2z M30.9,3.5C17.6,3.5,6.8,14.4,6.8,27.6c0,13.3,10.8,24.1,24.101,24.1C44.2,51.7,55,40.9,55,27.6C54.9,14.4,44.1,3.5,30.9,3.5z M36.9,35.8c0,0.601-0.4,1-0.9,1h-1.3c-0.5,0-0.9-0.399-0.9-1V19.5c0-0.6,0.4-1,0.9-1H36c0.5,0,0.9,0.4,0.9,1V35.8z M27.8,35.8 c0,0.601-0.4,1-0.9,1h-1.3c-0.5,0-0.9-0.399-0.9-1V19.5c0-0.6,0.4-1,0.9-1H27c0.5,0,0.9,0.4,0.9,1L27.8,35.8L27.8,35.8z'

If symbols needs to be different, you can set with callback function in the following format:

(value: Array|number, params: Object) => string

The first parameter value is the value in data, and the second parameter params is the rest parameters of data item.

markPoint.symbolSize.desc:
symbol size. It can be set to single numbers like 10, or use an array to represent width and height. For example, [20, 10] means symbol width is 20, and height is10.

If size of symbols needs to be different, you can set with callback function in the following format:

(value: Array|number, params: Object) => number|Array

The first parameter value is the value in data, and the second parameter params is the rest parameters of data item.

markPoint.symbolRotate.desc:
Rotate degree of symbol. The negative value represents clockwise. Note that when symbol is set to be 'arrow' in markLine, symbolRotate value will be ignored, and compulsively use tangent angle.

If rotation of symbols needs to be different, you can set with callback function in the following format:

(value: Array|number, params: Object) => number

The first parameter value is the value in data, and the second parameter params is the rest parameters of data item.

Callback is supported since 4.8.0 .

markPoint.symbolKeepAspect.desc: Whether to keep aspect for symbols in the form of path://.

markPoint.symbolOffset.desc:
Offset of symbol relative to original position. By default, symbol will be put in the center position of data. But if symbol is from user-defined vector path or image, you may not expect symbol to be in center. In this case, you may use this attribute to set offset to default position. It can be in absolute pixel value, or in relative percentage value.

For example, [0, '-50%'] means to move upside side position of symbol height. It can be used to make the arrow in the bottom to be at data position when symbol is pin.

markPoint.silent.desc: Whether to ignore mouse events. Default value is false, for triggering and responding to mouse events.

markPoint.label.position.desc:
Label position.

Followings are the options:

  • [x, y]

    Use relative percentage, or absolute pixel values to represent position of label relative to top-left corner of bounding box. For example:

      // Absolute pixel values
  position: [10, 10],
  // Relative percentage
  position: ['50%', '50%']

  • 'top'

  • 'left'
  • 'right'
  • 'bottom'
  • 'inside'
  • 'insideLeft'
  • 'insideRight'
  • 'insideTop'
  • 'insideBottom'
  • 'insideTopLeft'
  • 'insideBottomLeft'
  • 'insideTopRight'
  • 'insideBottomRight'

See: label position.

markPoint.label.distance.desc:
Distance to the host graphic element.

It is valid only when position is string value (like 'top'、'insideRight').

See: label position.

markPoint.label.rotate.desc:
Rotate label, from -90 degree to 90, positive value represents rotate anti-clockwise.

See: label rotation.

markPoint.label.offset.desc: Whether to move text slightly. For example: [30, 40] means move 30 horizontally and move 40 vertically.

markPoint.label.formatter.desc:
Data label formatter, which supports string template and callback function. In either form, \n is supported to represent a new line.

String template

Model variation includes:

  • {a}: series name.
  • {b}: the name of a data item.
  • {c}: the value of a data item.
  • {@xxx}: the value of a dimension named 'xxx', for example, {@product} refers the value of 'product' dimension.
  • {@[n]}: the value of a dimension at the index of n, for example, {@[3]} refers the value at dimensions[3].

example: 

formatter: '{b}: {@score}'

Callback function

Callback function is in form of:

(params: Object|Array) => string

where params is the single dataset needed by formatter, which is formed as:

{
    componentType: 'series',
    // Series type
    seriesType: string,
    // Series index in option.series
    seriesIndex: number,
    // Series name
    seriesName: string,
    // Data name, or category name
    name: string,
    // Data index in input data array
    dataIndex: number,
    // Original data as input
    data: Object,
    // Value of data. In most series it is the same as data.
    // But in some series it is some part of the data (e.g., in map, radar)
    value: number|Array|Object,
    // encoding info of coordinate system
    // Key: coord, like ('x' 'y' 'radius' 'angle')
    // value: Must be an array, not null/undefined. Contain dimension indices, like:
    // {
    //     x: [2] // values on dimension index 2 are mapped to x axis.
    //     y: [0] // values on dimension index 0 are mapped to y axis.
    // }
    encode: Object,
    // dimension names list
    dimensionNames: Array<String>,
    // data dimension index, for example 0 or 1 or 2 ...
    // Only work in `radar` series.
    dimensionIndex: number,
    // Color of data
    color: string
}

How to use encode and dimensionNames?

When the dataset is like

dataset: {
    source: [
        ['Matcha Latte', 43.3, 85.8, 93.7],
        ['Milk Tea', 83.1, 73.4, 55.1],
        ['Cheese Cocoa', 86.4, 65.2, 82.5],
        ['Walnut Brownie', 72.4, 53.9, 39.1]
    ]
}

We can get the value of the y-axis via

params.value[params.encode.y[0]]

When the dataset is like

dataset: {
    dimensions: ['product', '2015', '2016', '2017'],
    source: [
        {product: 'Matcha Latte', '2015': 43.3, '2016': 85.8, '2017': 93.7},
        {product: 'Milk Tea', '2015': 83.1, '2016': 73.4, '2017': 55.1},
        {product: 'Cheese Cocoa', '2015': 86.4, '2016': 65.2, '2017': 82.5},
        {product: 'Walnut Brownie', '2015': 72.4, '2016': 53.9, '2017': 39.1}
    ]
}

We can get the value of the y-axis via

params.value[params.dimensionNames[params.encode.y[0]]]

Since v5.0.0, it can also be a number or a number array to specify the dash array of the line. With borderDashOffset , we can make the line style more flexible.

For example：

{

borderType: [5, 10],

borderDashOffset: 5
}

markPoint.itemStyle.borderDashOffset.desc:
Since v5.0.0

To set the line dash offset. With borderType , we can make the line style more flexible.

Refer to MDN lineDashOffset for more details.

markPoint.itemStyle.borderCap.desc:
Since v5.0.0

To specify how to draw the end points of the line. Possible values are:

  • 'butt': The ends of lines are squared off at the endpoints.
  • 'round': The ends of lines are rounded.
  • 'square': The ends of lines are squared off by adding a box with an equal width and half the height of the line's thickness.

Default value is 'butt'. Refer to MDN lineCap for more details.

markPoint.itemStyle.borderJoin.desc:
Since v5.0.0

To determine the shape used to join two line segments where they meet.

Possible values are:

  • 'bevel': Fills an additional triangular area between the common endpoint of connected segments, and the separate outside rectangular corners of each segment.
  • 'round': Rounds off the corners of a shape by filling an additional sector of disc centered at the common endpoint of connected segments. The radius for these rounded corners is equal to the line width.
  • 'miter': Connected segments are joined by extending their outside edges to connect at a single point, with the effect of filling an additional lozenge-shaped area. This setting is affected by the borderMiterLimit property.

Default value is 'bevel'. Refer to MDN lineJoin for more details.

markPoint.itemStyle.borderMiterLimit.desc:
Since v5.0.0

To set the miter limit ratio. Only works when borderJoin is set as miter.

Default value is 10. Negative、0、Infinity and NaN values are ignored.

Refer to MDN miterLimit for more details.

markPoint.itemStyle.shadowBlur.desc:
Size of shadow blur. This attribute should be used along with shadowColor,shadowOffsetX, shadowOffsetY to set shadow to component.

For example:

{
    shadowColor: 'rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.5)',
    shadowBlur: 10
}

markPoint.itemStyle.shadowColor.desc: Shadow color. Support same format as color.

markPoint.itemStyle.shadowOffsetX.desc: Offset distance on the horizontal direction of shadow.

markPoint.itemStyle.shadowOffsetY.desc: Offset distance on the vertical direction of shadow.

markPoint.itemStyle.opacity.desc: Opacity of the component. Supports value from 0 to 1, and the component will not be drawn when set to 0.

markPoint.emphasis.disabled.desc:
Since v5.3.0

Whether to disable the emphasis state.

When emphasis state is disabled. There will be no highlight effect when the mouse hovered the element, tooltip is triggered, or the legend is hovered. It can be used to improve interaction fluency when there are massive graphic elements.

markPoint.emphasis.label.position.desc:
Label position.

Followings are the options:

  • [x, y]

    Use relative percentage, or absolute pixel values to represent position of label relative to top-left corner of bounding box. For example:

      // Absolute pixel values
  position: [10, 10],
  // Relative percentage
  position: ['50%', '50%']

  • 'top'

  • 'left'
  • 'right'
  • 'bottom'
  • 'inside'
  • 'insideLeft'
  • 'insideRight'
  • 'insideTop'
  • 'insideBottom'
  • 'insideTopLeft'
  • 'insideBottomLeft'
  • 'insideTopRight'
  • 'insideBottomRight'

See: label position.

markPoint.emphasis.label.distance.desc:
Distance to the host graphic element.

It is valid only when position is string value (like 'top'、'insideRight').

See: label position.

markPoint.emphasis.label.rotate.desc:
Rotate label, from -90 degree to 90, positive value represents rotate anti-clockwise.

See: label rotation.

markPoint.emphasis.label.offset.desc: Whether to move text slightly. For example: [30, 40] means move 30 horizontally and move 40 vertically.

markPoint.emphasis.label.formatter.desc:
Data label formatter, which supports string template and callback function. In either form, \n is supported to represent a new line.

String template

Model variation includes:

  • {a}: series name.
  • {b}: the name of a data item.
  • {c}: the value of a data item.
  • {@xxx}: the value of a dimension named 'xxx', for example, {@product} refers the value of 'product' dimension.
  • {@[n]}: the value of a dimension at the index of n, for example, {@[3]} refers the value at dimensions[3].

example: 

formatter: '{b}: {@score}'

Callback function

Callback function is in form of:

(params: Object|Array) => string

where params is the single dataset needed by formatter, which is formed as:

{
    componentType: 'series',
    // Series type
    seriesType: string,
    // Series index in option.series
    seriesIndex: number,
    // Series name
    seriesName: string,
    // Data name, or category name
    name: string,
    // Data index in input data array
    dataIndex: number,
    // Original data as input
    data: Object,
    // Value of data. In most series it is the same as data.
    // But in some series it is some part of the data (e.g., in map, radar)
    value: number|Array|Object,
    // encoding info of coordinate system
    // Key: coord, like ('x' 'y' 'radius' 'angle')
    // value: Must be an array, not null/undefined. Contain dimension indices, like:
    // {
    //     x: [2] // values on dimension index 2 are mapped to x axis.
    //     y: [0] // values on dimension index 0 are mapped to y axis.
    // }
    encode: Object,
    // dimension names list
    dimensionNames: Array<String>,
    // data dimension index, for example 0 or 1 or 2 ...
    // Only work in `radar` series.
    dimensionIndex: number,
    // Color of data
    color: string
}

How to use encode and dimensionNames?

When the dataset is like

dataset: {
    source: [
        ['Matcha Latte', 43.3, 85.8, 93.7],
        ['Milk Tea', 83.1, 73.4, 55.1],
        ['Cheese Cocoa', 86.4, 65.2, 82.5],
        ['Walnut Brownie', 72.4, 53.9, 39.1]
    ]
}

We can get the value of the y-axis via

params.value[params.encode.y[0]]

When the dataset is like

dataset: {
    dimensions: ['product', '2015', '2016', '2017'],
    source: [
        {product: 'Matcha Latte', '2015': 43.3, '2016': 85.8, '2017': 93.7},
        {product: 'Milk Tea', '2015': 83.1, '2016': 73.4, '2017': 55.1},
        {product: 'Cheese Cocoa', '2015': 86.4, '2016': 65.2, '2017': 82.5},
        {product: 'Walnut Brownie', '2015': 72.4, '2016': 53.9, '2017': 39.1}
    ]
}

We can get the value of the y-axis via

params.value[params.dimensionNames[params.encode.y[0]]]

markPoint.emphasis.label.color.desc:
text color.

If set as 'inherit', the color will assigned as visual color, such as series color.

markPoint.emphasis.label.align.desc:
Horizontal alignment of text, automatic by default.

Options are:

  • 'left'
  • 'center'
  • 'right'

If align is not set in rich, align in parent level will be used. For example:

{
    align: right,
    rich: {
        a: {
            // `align` is not set, then it will be right
        }
    }
}

markPoint.emphasis.label.verticalAlign.desc:
Vertical alignment of text, automatic by default.

Options are:

  • 'top'
  • 'middle'
  • 'bottom'

If verticalAlign is not set in rich, verticalAlign in parent level will be used. For example:

{
    verticalAlign: bottom,
    rich: {
        a: {
            // `verticalAlign` is not set, then it will be bottom
        }
    }
}

markPoint.emphasis.label.lineHeight.desc:
Line height of the text fragment.

If lineHeight is not set in rich, lineHeight in parent level will be used. For example:

{
    lineHeight: 56,
    rich: {
        a: {
            // `lineHeight` is not set, then it will be 56
        }
    }
}

markPoint.emphasis.label.backgroundColor.desc:
Background color of the text fragment.

Can be color string, like '#123234', 'red', 'rgba(0,23,11,0.3)'.

Or image can be used, for example:

backgroundColor: {
    image: 'xxx/xxx.png'
    // It can be URL of a image,
    // or dataURI,
    // or HTMLImageElement,
    // or HTMLCanvasElement.
}

width or height can be specified when using background image, or auto adapted by default.

If set as 'inherit', the color will assigned as visual color, such as series color.

markPoint.emphasis.label.borderColor.desc:
Border color of the text fragment.

If set as 'inherit', the color will assigned as visual color, such as series color.

markPoint.emphasis.label.borderType.desc:
the text fragment border type.

Possible values are:

  • 'solid'
  • 'dashed'
  • 'dotted'

Since v5.0.0, it can also be a number or a number array to specify the dash array of the line. With borderDashOffset , we can make the line style more flexible.

For example：

{

borderType: [5, 10],

borderDashOffset: 5
}

markPoint.emphasis.label.borderDashOffse.desc:
Since v5.0.0

To set the line dash offset. With borderType , we can make the line style more flexible.

Refer to MDN lineDashOffset for more details.

markPoint.emphasis.label.padding.desc:
Padding of the text fragment, for example:

  • padding: [3, 4, 5, 6]: represents padding of [top, right, bottom, left].
  • padding: 4: represents padding: [4, 4, 4, 4].
  • padding: [3, 4]: represents padding: [3, 4, 3, 4].

Notice, width and height specifies the width and height of the content, without padding.

markPoint.emphasis.label.shadowOffsetX.desc: Shadow X offset of the text block.

markPoint.emphasis.label.shadowOffsetY.desc: Shadow Y offset of the text block.

markPoint.emphasis.label.textBorderColor.desc:
Stroke color of the text.

If set as 'inherit', the color will assigned as visual color, such as series color.

markPoint.emphasis.label.textBorderType.desc:
Stroke line type of the text.

Possible values are:

  • 'solid'
  • 'dashed'
  • 'dotted'

Since v5.0.0, it can also be a number or a number array to specify the dash array of the line. With textBorderDashOffset , we can make the line style more flexible.

For example：

{

textBorderType: [5, 10],

textBorderDashOffset: 5
}

markPoint.emphasis.label.textBorderDashO.desc:
Since v5.0.0

To set the line dash offset. With textBorderType , we can make the line style more flexible.

Refer to MDN lineDashOffset for more details.

markPoint.emphasis.label.textShadowOffse.desc: Shadow X offset of the text itself.
Shadow Y offset of the text itself.

markPoint.emphasis.label.overflow.desc:
Determine how to display the text when it's overflow. Available when width is set.

  • 'truncate' Truncate the text and trailing with ellipsis.
  • 'break' Break by word
  • 'breakAll' Break by character.

markPoint.emphasis.label.ellipsis.desc:
Ellipsis to be displayed when overflow is set to truncate.

  • 'truncate' Truncate the overflow lines.

markPoint.emphasis.label.rich.desc:
"Rich text styles" can be defined in this rich property. For example:

label: {
    // Styles defined in 'rich' can be applied to some fragments
    // of text by adding some markers to those fragment, like
    // `{styleName|text content text content}`.
    // `'\n'` is the newline character.
    formatter: [
        '{a|Style "a" is applied to this snippet}'
        '{b|Style "b" is applied to this snippet}This snippet use default style{x|use style "x"}'
    ].join('\n'),

    rich: {
        a: {
            color: 'red',
            lineHeight: 10
        },
        b: {
            backgroundColor: {
                image: 'xxx/xxx.jpg'
            },
            height: 40
        },
        x: {
            fontSize: 18,
            fontFamily: 'Microsoft YaHei',
            borderColor: '#449933',
            borderRadius: 4
        },
        ...
    }
}

For more details, see Rich Text please.

Width of the text block. It is the width of the text by default. In most cases, there is no need to specify it. You may want to use it in some cases like make simple table or using background image (see backgroundColor).

Notice, width and height specifies the width and height of the content, without padding.

width can also be percent string, like '100%', which represents the percent of contentWidth (that is, the width without padding) of its container box. It is based on contentWidth because that each text fragment is layout based on the content box, where it makes no sense that calculating width based on outerWith in prectice.

markPoint.blur.label.rich.desc:
"Rich text styles" can be defined in this rich property. For example:

label: {
    // Styles defined in 'rich' can be applied to some fragments
    // of text by adding some markers to those fragment, like
    // `{styleName|text content text content}`.
    // `'\n'` is the newline character.
    formatter: [
        '{a|Style "a" is applied to this snippet}'
        '{b|Style "b" is applied to this snippet}This snippet use default style{x|use style "x"}'
    ].join('\n'),

    rich: {
        a: {
            color: 'red',
            lineHeight: 10
        },
        b: {
            backgroundColor: {
                image: 'xxx/xxx.jpg'
            },
            height: 40
        },
        x: {
            fontSize: 18,
            fontFamily: 'Microsoft YaHei',
            borderColor: '#449933',
            borderRadius: 4
        },
        ...
    }
}

For more details, see Rich Text please.

markPoint.blur.label.rich.<style_name>.c.desc:

  • 'left'
  • 'center'
  • 'right'

If align is not set in rich, align in parent level will be used. For example:

{

    rich: {

            // `align` is not set, then it will be right
        }
    }
}

Can be color string, like '#123234', 'red', 'rgba(0,23,11,0.3)'.

backgroundColor: {

width or height can be specified when using background image, or auto adapted by default.

If set as 'inherit', the color will assigned as visual color, such as series color.

markPoint.blur.label.rich.<style_name>.s.desc: Shadow X offset of the text block.
Shadow Y offset of the text block.

markPoint.blur.label.rich.<style_name>.w.desc:
Width of the text block. It is the width of the text by default. In most cases, there is no need to specify it. You may want to use it in some cases like make simple table or using background image (see backgroundColor).

Notice, width and height specifies the width and height of the content, without padding.

width can also be percent string, like '100%', which represents the percent of contentWidth (that is, the width without padding) of its container box. It is based on contentWidth because that each text fragment is layout based on the content box, where it makes no sense that calculating width based on outerWith in prectice.

Notice, width and height only work when rich specified.

markPoint.blur.label.rich.<style_name>.h.desc:

markPoint.blur.itemStyle.borderColor.desc: border color, whose format is similar to that of color.

border width. No border when it is set to be 0.

  • 'dashed'

{
